qas.question: Which of Popper's works addresses the improvement of scientific understanding of the world over time?
Popper described the growth of scientific understanding as what kind of process?
What aspect of a scientific theory can never be fully verified, according to Popper?
In what book did Popper seek to explain the process of literary knowledge?
Who explained why our understanding of the universe seems to worsen over time?
What part of theories can be verified by scientific testing?
What was the advance of scientific knowledge in Einstein's view?

context: In <a0_0><b3_0>All Life is Problem Solving<b3_0/><a0_0/>, <b4_0>Popper<b4_0/> sought to explain the apparent progress of scientific knowledge – that is, how it is that our understanding of the universe seems to improve over time. This problem arises from his position that the <a2_0><b5_0>truth content<b5_0/><a2_0/> of our theories, even the best of them, cannot be verified by scientific testing, but can only be falsified. Again, in this context <b6_0>the word "falsified"<b6_0/> does not refer to something being "fake"; rather, that something can be (i.e., is capable of being) shown to be false by observation or experiment. Some things simply do not lend themselves to being shown to be false, and therefore, are not falsifiable. If so, then how is it that the growth of science appears to result in a growth in knowledge? In Popper's view, the advance of scientific knowledge is an <a1_0><b7_0>evolutionary<a1_0/> process<b7_0/> characterised by his formula:
